It seems like at first glance the simplest thing to do with a CPPN
would be=
 to search for the shape or comformation of some protein or
molecule that w=
ould produce some sort of desired binding.  However,
that is not exactly th=
e problem you are describing; rather, you are
suggesting something more lik=
e a scoring system that looks at two
interacting pieces and rates their int=
eraction.  Perhaps something
like that would be served well by HyperNEAT, w=
hich can form a neural
network based on the geometric configuration of its =
inputs.  The
possibilities would obviously need to still be fleshed out.

k=
en

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@...> wrote:
>
> =
You've captured the basic idea.  Let me expand on it a bit.
> 
> One of the=
 currently leading problems in computational chemistry or
> molecular model=
ing is coming up with a method to predict the affinity
> of a small molecul=
e for the binding site of a protein.  In the case
> where you have a model =
of the binding site (typically from a crystal
> structure), there are tools=
 that will accurately position a small
> molecule into the binding site, ho=
wever, there is not a good scoring
> function that will give you an estimat=
e of the activity that small
> molecule will have against the protein.  It =
seems counter-intuitive -
> we can accurately place the molecule in the rig=
ht 3D conformation into
> the 3D binding site, but we can't really tell you=
 how active it will
> be.  In other cases you do not have a model of the pr=
otein.  In both
> cases you may have a number of compounds for which the ac=
tivity is
known.
> 
> For small molecules to bind to a protein/enzyme, they=
 will be required
> to make a number of interactions with that protein.  Th=
is implies that
> they must be the correct shape, obviously, but they must =
also place
> the correct types of atoms/groups in the right place to make t=
hose
> interactions.  Often, the bulk of the compound is used to place thin=
gs
> into the right locations in order to get an interaction - to get the
>=
 right shape.
> 
> Given the CPPN's ability to capture spatial relationship=
s, I'm
> wondering if it could be used as an evaluator for the strength of =
an
> interaction of this sort.  The spatial relationships of interest may
>=
 stem from the small molecules themselves, the protein binding site, or
> a=
 combination of the two.  All of this is going on in a 3D space
> defined b=
y the protein binding site.
> 
> Obviously I need to think about this furth=
er, but there very well may
> be something useful here that hasn't yet been=
 tried.  
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley=
" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Kirk, I think that's a very interesting potent=
ial application area.  
> > Let me make sure I'm understanding how it would=
 work.  You are saying
> > that you might capture the shape of a protein bi=
nding region (or some
> > other important region) with a CPPN and then use =
that CPPN-encoded
> > model to test other chemical compounds?  
> > 
> > Bu=
t if you already have a model of the intended shape, what additional
> > ca=
pability would the CPPN provide other than encoding the 3D model
> > that y=
ou already have?  Or do you mean you might try creating new
> > shapes with=
 the CPPN that you haven't thought of and see how they
> > react with known=
 compounds?  There are probably other ways it could go
> > as well, but I'm=
 curious from the point of view of computational
> > chemistry where the mo=
st exciting opportunity would be.  
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:
> > >
> > > I may be over-in=
terpreting the CPPN process, but it stimulated a few
> > > ideas.  I work i=
n the field of Computational Chemistry and my in my
> > > day to day operat=
ions I deal with drug-like chemical compounds.  The
> > > 3D shape of a che=
mical is a principle determining factor of its
> > > activity.  On top of 3=
D shape, you have different functional groups
> > > that impart different p=
roperties.  For example, let's say the
shape is
> > > just right to bind to=
 a particular enzyme (and prevent it from
running
> > > amok) but you need =
an oxygen atom at a particular location, or a
> > > nitrogen, or any atom w=
ith a hydrogen attached, etc.
> > > 
> > > There are two ways to get to thi=
s type of information.  First is
> > > having a large collection of chemica=
ls with a known endpoint.  For
> > > this I usually apply the standard patt=
ern recognition tools. 
Another
> > > more difficult approach is when you d=
on't have much data for
> > > chemicals, but you know the 3D structure of t=
he enzyme and where you
> > > want your chemical to bind.  I'm wondering if=
 there is an
application
> > > for CPPNs here.  Can the CPPN capture the sh=
ape of the site
along with
> > > the essential properties based on the prot=
ein itself and then be
used
> > > to assess different chemical compounds th=
at have not yet been
tested -
> > > try to predict their activities.
> > > =

> > > Any thoughts??
> > > 
> > > -Kirk
> > > 
> > > 
> > >

neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > =
Kirk, what is your idea for applying CPPNs to pattern
> recognition?  I
> >=
 > > am not sure I followed exactly how the CPPN would be connected
> to th=
e
> > > > neural network?
> > > > 
> > > > As Peter mentioned, we have used=
 the idea of CPPNs to represent
> > > > connectivity patterns rather than t=
he spatial patterns you saw
> in the
> > > > CPPN paper.  These connectivit=
y patterns can then be
interpreted of
> > > > neural network connectivity p=
atterns, which means you can evolve
> > > > neural networks with regulariti=
es in their connectivities. 
> There are
> > > > currently four papers on t=
his approach to evolving ANNs with
CPPNs,
> > > > which is called HyperNEAT=
.  Those papers are available from my
> > homepage
> > > > 
> > > > http://=
www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/
> > > > 
> > > > or from EPlex publications:

 particular papers are:
> > > > 
> > > > -A Novel Generative Encoding for E=
xploiting Neural Network
> Sensor and 
> > > > Output Geometry
> > > > 
> >=
 > > -Generating Large-Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering
> Geometri=
c
> > > > Regularities 
> > > > 
> > > > -A Case Study on the Critical Role=
 of Geometric Regularity in
> Machine
> > > > Learning
> > > > 
> > > > -Ge=
nerative Encoding for Multiagent Learning 
> > > > 
> > > > A longer journa=
l paper on HyperNEAT is also forthcoming in
> Artificial
> > > > Life journ=
al.
> > > > 
> > > > By the way, you can also interactively evolve your own=
 CPPNs
images
> > > > online at http://picbreeder.org
> > > > 
> > > > Beca=
use spatial patterns and connectivity patterns can represent
> just
> > > >=
 about anything, there are other potential applications of CPPNs
> beyond
>=
 > > > representing ANNs, but currently there is no publication of
such an
=
> > > > application that I know of.  But it would be interesting to
see mor=
e
> > > > work in that direction.
